The resolved structure where Ne dissolved in ice II is thermodynamically stable at 480 MPa and 260 K. The density distributions indicate that the vibration of Ne atoms is mainly in planes perpendicular to D2O channels, whereas their distributions along the channels are further constrained by interactions between adjacent Ne atoms. Our work provides a new route to study the structure of ice II and opens up a new avenue for the study of hydrates at high pressure. The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. Our approach is based on the notion of a Hilbert category, which is a generalization of a category that generalizes the notion of a Hilbert space. We show that the category of Hilbert spaces is equivalent to the category of continuous linear functions between Hilbert spaces. This result is a step toward a reconstruction of quantum theory in terms of a suitable category of Hilbert categories.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are the most diverse group of parasitic animals. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present the first comparative genomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species and a cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the IFN antagonism mechanism used by SARS-CoV-2 and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the Hv1 channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. (Show more)

Climate change will increase the variability of global crop yields, making it more difficult to achieve food security. We quantify the magnitude of this increase in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase dramatically. These results highlight the need for increased investments in breeding for heat tolerance. They also underscore the urgency of these investments, as the 800 million people living in extreme poverty are most vulnerable to food price spikes. Our results show that the instability in global grain trade and international grain prices will become more pronounced as the Earth warms. This instability will affect especially the poorest countries, which are also the most vulnerable to food price spikes.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because species-level identification of food plants is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the need for more comprehensive methods to identify food plants in future studies of LMH diet partitioning. This will be critical to understanding the role of LMH in the maintenance of biodiversity in African savanna. (Less)

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. Our findings suggest that the crisis is already having a significant impact on small businesses, with many already laying off workers and closing their doors. Moreover, many small businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many small businesses are uncertain about the length of the crisis, and some anticipate that they will be unable to access the CARES Act. These findings have implications for policymakers seeking to support small businesses during the crisis.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. This study is of great importance to the scientific community and to society.

The age of the solar system is one of the most fundamental facts in astronomy. It is based on the assumption that the solar system is a typical place in the universe. However, the age of the solar system is not a simple number. It is a number that depends on the age of the oldest objects in the solar system. The oldest objects in the solar system are the meteorites. Meteorites are the building blocks of the solar system. They are the oldest objects in the solar system. Therefore, the age of the solar system is determined by the age of the oldest meteorites. The age of the oldest meteorites is determined by the age of the oldest grains in the meteorites. These grains are the building blocks of the oldest meteorites. Therefore, the age of the oldest meteorites is determined by the age of the oldest grains in the oldest meteorites. This is a very complicated process. We have developed a method to determine the age of the oldest grains in the oldest meteorites. We have applied this method to the oldest grains in the oldest meteorite. The age of the oldest grains in the oldest meteorite is 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources. This study provides a comprehensive picture of the evolution of the global fishing fleet and its impact on the ocean. It is a valuable resource for policymakers and scientists. It is also a call to action to reduce the impact of the fishing fleet on the ocean.

The ability to reproduce is the defining characteristic of all living organisms. In this study, we investigate the factors that limit reproductive output in mammals. We find that the greatest limiting factor is maternal metabolic power. This finding is important because it suggests that the evolution of mammals was driven by the evolution of the mother, rather than the evolution of the environment. This finding has implications for the evolution of placental mammals and the evolution of life itself.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is a hallmark of MSA pathology. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This hypothesis is supported by the fact that VX-765 was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the potential of VX-765 to limit α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in MSA. This study also highlights the potential of VX-765 to be used as a therapeutic agent in other synucleinopathies. (Synucleinopathies

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It controls vascular function, including hemostasis, inflammation, and oxygen and nutrient exchange between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cell types that are connected by a network of communication channels. The network is critical for the endothelium to function properly, but the nature of the network is poorly understood. Here, we show that the endothelium is organized into a small-world network, which is a configuration that is known to be effective for efficient communication. The network is also highly dynamic, with cells able to rapidly and robustly communicate with each other. These findings reveal the design principles of the endothelium and provide insight into the structure and function of the vascular system. Understanding the structure of the vascular system is critical for understanding and treating cardiovascular disease. This work provides a new perspective on the structure of the vascular system and may lead to new approaches for treating cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are critical for understanding the pandemic and for making informed decisions about the pandemic. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the pandemic, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. The COVIDcast API is available at https://github.com/COVIDcast/covidcast-api. The data are available at https://github.com/COVIDcast/covidcast-data. The software packages are available at https://github.com/COVIDcast/covidcast-r and https://github.com/COVIDcast/covidcast-python.

This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host and the environment. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is still being elucidated, and the potential of the microbiome to produce bioactive compounds has been recognized for some time. Here, we report the discovery of a large number of natural products that are produced by anaerobic fungi that inhabit the gastrointestinal tract of herbivores. These fungi are a previously understudied source of natural products, and the results of this study could lead to the discovery of new compounds with a wide range of potential applications. This study also highlights the potential of anaerobic fungi to produce natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the underlying mechanisms remain largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by the brain energy metabolism. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the social behavior of individuals with high anxiety and may lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches. The ability to design and manufacture complex mechanical devices with specific and extreme responses is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures, which seamlessly collaborate to produce the target responses. The structures are digitally synthesized with irregular material distributions and complex shapes, yet are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general approach to design and manufacture complex mechanical devices with specific and extreme responses. It also provides a new perspective to understand the deformation mechanisms of materials and structures. It is expected to inspire the design of mechanical devices with specific and extreme responses in various fields. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the development of mechanical design and manufacturing.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development in vertebrates. The hemoglobin system is also a target of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 mRNA-binding protein is a key player in the human hemoglobin system. We show that IGF2BP1 is downregulated in human fetal erythroid tissues and that IGF2BP1 overexpression in human erythroid cells results in a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin pattern. This reversal is mediated by a decrease in the expression of the adult hemoglobin genes and an increase in fetal hemoglobin. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of the hemoglobin system in humans. This mechanism may be important for the development of hemoglobin disorders and for the regulation of fetal hemoglobin in humans. This work also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobin disorders. (HbA2)

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, many patients do not respond to current therapies. In this study, we identified a mechanism of cancer resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through the transcription factor sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1) and its target stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1). We also found that SREBP1 and SCD1 are frequently mutated in cancer, and that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. These findings suggest that combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) through a mechanism involving STIM1. Our findings have implications for the use of LCCBs in patients with advanced hypertension and/or heart failure. The use of LCCBs in elderly patients should be carefully considered. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study provides a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrates that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way federal forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was effective in halting the decline of early-seral ecosystems, but that the policy failed to halt the decline of older forests. Our findings underscore the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the importance of monitoring and adaptive management to ensure that policies are effective and to identify when they are not. This study provides a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. The approach is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. We tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The approach described here is a promising strategy for the discovery of new antibiotics. It can be easily extended to other drug classes and can be used in combination with other computational and experimental approaches. This approach can be applied to other drug classes, such as antivirals, antifungals, and antiparasitics. It can also be extended to other drug targets, such as the enzyme DNA polymerase. The approach can be used to design new drugs

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations. The resulting architecture is able to adapt to different problems, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. Our results suggest that the proposed architecture is a promising alternative to existing architectures for many image-processing problems. The code for the proposed architecture is available at https://github.com/yannickdelange/simple_net.git.

The evolution of the African continent and its associated ecosystems is closely linked to the climate of the tropics. We present a 1.3-My record of the hydroclimate of the tropics, derived from a drill core from Lake Malawi. The record shows a dramatic shift in the effective moisture of the tropics at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition, which is consistent with the onset of the African Humid Period. The hydroclimate variability observed during the last glacial period is unprecedented in the last 1.3 My, and the lake level variations are far more extreme than observed today. The lake level variations exerted a profound influence on the evolution of the endemic cichlid fish species flock. The rapid evolution of the species flock is consistent with the hypothesis that the lake level variations provided novel ecological opportunities, enabling new populations to differentiate rapidly to distinct species. The results provide a unique insight into the hydroclimate of the tropics and the evolution of the African continent. (Less)

The use of electronic devices, such as computers and smartphones, has increased dramatically in the past decade. This study shows that the use of these devices in the hours before bedtime has a negative impact on sleep. Specifically, the use of electronic devices phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and reduces the next-morning alertness. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known abrupt climate change that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope compositions of the YDB samples are consistent with a terrestrial origin. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the YDB spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. The Os in the spherules is likely terrestrial in origin. These results support the hypothesis that one or more bolide impacts triggered the Younger Dryas cooling. (Less)

CTLA-4 is a negative regulator of T cell activation, but its specific role in the development of autoimmune and other diseases is unknown. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice results in the development of a variety of autoimmune diseases, including myocarditis, gastritis, insulitis, pneumonitis, and sialadenitis. These diseases are not fatal, but they are accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. In contrast, congenital deficiency of CTLA-4 is lethal, but it is not associated with the development of autoimmunity. These findings indicate that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice has a profound effect on the development of autoimmunity. This effect is not limited to the development of T cell tolerance, but also involves the development of autoantibodies. These findings have implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 beetle genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, and to trace the evolution of beetle species and genes over time. Our results suggest that the evolution of specialized herbivory in beetles was driven by the convergent acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that degrade plant cell walls. These results have implications for our understanding of the evolution of animal diversity and the origins of plant-feeding habits. (Show more)

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of approved vaccines and antibodies. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. We demonstrate the utility of our approach by optimizing the binding affinity of a human antibody, P36-5D2, to SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. Our optimized antibody is ∼10- to 600-fold more potent than the original antibody against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be used to optimize other protein molecules, such as vaccines and therapeutics, to improve their effectiveness against emerging variants. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work provides a new approach to antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary biologists and cultural anthropologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology and the cultural transmission of ideas. They also suggest that the evolution of technology may be more complex than previously thought. This work is a contribution to the debate on the role of culture in the evolution of technology. It is also a contribution to the debate on the role of culture in the evolution of technology.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with an ∼12-fold increased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that the amount of C1q protein accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration, is highly dependent on APOE alleles: C1q accumulation was significantly reduced in APOE2 knock-in (KI) animals and was significantly increased in APOE4 KI

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the outer core by a brittle boundary. The inner core is a unique natural laboratory that can provide insights into the formation of the Earth and the solidification process of metals. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still poorly understood. This study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core by revealing that the bcc phase of iron is more stable than the hcp phase under inner core conditions. This finding provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox, which has been a long-standing problem in geophysics. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and the solidification process of metals. It also has implications for the formation of other solid cores in other planets. Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are key features of marijuana addiction. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of marijuana on the brain and for the development of effective treatments for marijuana addiction.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the human brain is uniquely adapted to process language. This has led some to speculate that language processing is a uniquely human cognitive system. Here, we show that a state-of-the-art deep learning model for natural language processing achieves high accuracy on a task that requires understanding of the semantics of language, and that this model predicts nearly all of the neural activity in the brain. These results provide computational evidence for the claim that language processing is a uniquely human cognitive system. They also suggest that the human brain is uniquely adapted to process language.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it is still a black box. This paper shows that the black box can be opened by understanding the conditions under which it is possible to train a neural network with a given accuracy. We prove that, for some problems, it is possible to train a neural network with a given accuracy, and we also prove that it is not possible to train a neural network with a given accuracy for other problems. This classification theory can be used to understand the limitations of neural networks. It also provides a foundation for understanding the stability of neural networks.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a failure of the human mind. This is based on a classic experiment published in 1975, which purported to show that people are unable to understand exponential growth. The experiment’s design flaws have been widely discussed, but the study’s conclusion has been largely ignored. This article discusses the flaws in the experiment’s design and how they led to the erroneous conclusion that people are unable to understand exponential growth. It also discusses the implications of this study for our understanding of human cognition and decision-making.

Leprosy is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide. Although the causative agent is known, the identity of the pathogen has been a matter of debate. Here, we present the genome sequence of a human pathogen, M. lepromatosis, which causes a reactional form of leprosy. The genome sequence reveals that the two leprosy pathogens are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Our findings have important implications for understanding the evolution of leprosy and the emergence of new pathogens. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the keystones of quantum information theory, where they are at the heart of the foundations of quantum communication and quantum computation. However, the relation between these two concepts is still poorly understood. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in integrable systems can be completely described in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is a major step forward in the study of the relation between entanglement and thermodynamics.

The COVID-19 pandemic is still ongoing, and there is a need for a safe and effective vaccine. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is highly attenuated and can be manufactured at large scale. This vaccine candidate, which is based on a segment of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein, is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, but robustly grows at the permissive temperature. The vaccine candidate generates high levels of neutralizing antibodies and is protective in hamsters. This vaccine candidate could be used in mass vaccination programs to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

Plague is a disease with a long history of outbreaks and pandemics. The Second Pandemic, which occurred between the 14th and 19th centuries, was characterized by high mortality and recurrent epidemics. The vector of plague during this period is still debated, with some studies suggesting that plague was spread by rats, while others suggest that human ectoparasite vectors, such as fleas or lice, were the primary vectors. Here, we present a mathematical model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites and show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work contributes to a better understanding of the history of plague and its vectors. It also provides a framework for studying the spread of plague in the future.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known driver of animal behavior. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is less understood. Here, we show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is also driven by the evolution of the number of neurons. We show that the number of neurons is much more important than brain size in explaining the evolution of brain information-processing capacity. This study has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study also highlights the need for more specific TRAP1 inhibitors. (TRAP1-specific inhibitors are not currently available.) Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the island was settled by multiple waves of migration, with a recent demographic growth. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide a better understanding of the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. People are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they are not aware of it. This phenomenon, called emotional contagion, has been studied in the laboratory, where it is easy to control. However, it is not clear whether emotional contagion occurs in the real world, where people are exposed to the emotions of others in a variety of contexts. We show that it does, by manipulating the amount of positive and negative content in the News Feed of Facebook. This work suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they are not aware of it, and that in-person interaction is not necessary for emotional contagion. It also suggests that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships, and that these associations are independent of factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms. These findings suggest that the feeling that one’s life is worthwhile may be a key factor in promoting healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining feature of aquatic mammals. We use a quantitative model of the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment to show that the evolution of larger body sizes is a consequence of the aquatic environment, not a release from it.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must sense and respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa detects the mechanical activity of its type IV pili, a major surface adhesin, on short timescales. This mechanosensitive signal transduction mechanism requires attachment of type IV pili to a solid surface, followed by pili retraction and signal transduction through the Chp chemosensory system, a chemotaxis-like sensory system that regulates cAMP production and transcription of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. These findings demonstrate that P. aeruginosa uses type IV pili for both twitching motility and as a sensor regulating surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This is the first report of a bacterial mechanosensitive system that detects the mechanical activity of a surface-associated protein. Our results also suggest that type IV pili may be a common sensor for bacteria to sense the mechanical activity of their environment. This finding may have important implications for the development of new antibacterial strategies. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and this trend is expected to continue. However, the consequences of pesticide use for the quality of surface waters are poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global situation and show that the biological integrity of water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest that the use of pesticides in agriculture should be reconsidered.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the ecology of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. Here, we describe the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also describe the rapid spread of the virus within the deer population. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We highlight the need for a more comprehensive and proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology and evolution of SARS-CoV-2. This approach is critical to understanding the potential for future outbreaks and the development of effective control measures. Our study provides a model for the rapid and effective implementation of such an approach. (Show more)

The hydropower industry has been building dams in the developing world for decades. The proliferation of large dams in the Mekong River Basin, the Amazon River Basin, and the Congo River Basin is a major concern because of the disruption of river ecology, deforestation, loss of biodiversity, greenhouse gas emissions, displacement of people, and changes to the food system, water quality, and agriculture. This paper examines the problems and proposes solutions to move hydropower toward sustainable practices.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins. Although the presence of Aβ plaques is the most common pathological feature of AD, we show that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ is also a significant contributor to the AD pathogenesis. We demonstrate that neurons, which are the primary cell type affected in AD, produce a variety of potent immune factors, both at the transcript and protein levels. These findings suggest that the intraneuronal Aβ burden may be a significant contributor to the AD pathology, and may even precede the formation of Aβ plaques. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron may serve as a primary target for therapeutic intervention. This study provides a new perspective on the AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still unknown. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics where systems can spontaneously reach a critical state. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity, which is the hallmark of criticality. The sandpile model is the first and archetypical model of SOC. In this paper, we study a continuous version of the sandpile model, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We show that this model exhibits SOC behavior. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

The discovery of antimicrobial peptides in animals and plants has led to the development of a new class of antimicrobial agents. However, the antifungal activity of peptides has been limited. The peptide also induced reactive oxygen species and compromised the integrity of the cell membrane. The peptide was effective against multiple plant fungal pathogens and could be applied as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work provides a foundation for the development of this class of peptides as a new class of antifungal agents. (Show more)

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth today is known to be strongly correlated with the amount of light available to the surface, and this correlation has been demonstrated in a variety of organisms. We show that the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past was also strongly correlated with the amount of light available to the surface. This finding has implications for the evolution of life on Earth.

Malaria parasite invasion of the red blood cell (RBC) is a critical step in the disease pathogenesis. The parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) is required for entry in most parasite strains, but the function of this binding interaction is unknown. Here, we show that EBA175 binding to glycophorin A (GPA) leads to an increase in the cytoskeletal tension of the red cell and a reduction in the bending modulus of the cell’s membrane. We isolate the changes in the cytoskeleton and membrane and show that reduction in the bending modulus is directly correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. These data suggest that the malaria parasite primes the erythrocyte surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up new avenues for the development of antimalarial strategies. (Show more)

While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic relations between words, but there is no direct evidence for this hypothesis. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but increases even more when words are merged into phrases. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity, providing evidence for a bottom-up parser of the incoming language stream. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is the first intracranial evidence for the merge operation postulated by linguists.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in development and homeostasis. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and its function is to convert signals at the plasma membrane to signals that inhibit the degradation of β-catenin, leading to its accumulation and specific gene activation. We show here that the two forms of Axin are similar at the protein level, but they are regulated differently. This differential regulation may be used to control the responsiveness of the pathway in different tissues.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. In this study, we show that stimulation of LH neurons that project to the lateral part of the LH (LH-L) causes rapid vigorous eating in sated animals. We also show that this circuit is critical for this effect, as it is not affected by lesions of the ventral tegmental area, the dopamine cell bodies in the substantia nigra, or the dopamine neurons in the nucleus accumbens. Finally, we show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work may help to understand the mechanisms that underlie the development of obesity. Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth and productivity, and the ability to engineer the nitrogen cycle in agriculture is therefore a key goal for sustainable food production. Here, we demonstrate the ability to control the nitrogen cycle in a plant–bacterial symbiosis, using a synthetic biology approach. We show that the plant can control the expression of genes involved in nitrogen metabolism in the bacterial symbiont, and that this control can be used to regulate nitrogen fixation. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This approach could be used to engineer other nitrogen-cycling organisms, such as denitrifying bacteria, and could be extended to other systems, such as the nitrogen cycle in the ocean. This work also represents a step toward the development of synthetic biology approaches for the control of the nitrogen cycle in the environment. (Show more)

The Peruvian Amazon is the most deforested region in the world, and the rate of deforestation is increasing. The Peruvian government has invested in remote-sensed monitoring systems, but these systems rarely reach the most directly affected communities in time to deter deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. This approach could be applied in other regions where deforestation is driven by local-level drivers.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. The spider’s hearing is outsourced to its web, which acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna. The spider can remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. The spider’s web is flexible and can be regenerated, allowing it to adjust and maintain its hearing surface area according to its needs. This study provides insights into the evolution of hearing and the design of acoustic flow detectors. It also offers a unique model for studying the regenerative sensing and supersizing of sensory function. (Show more)

The health and climate impacts of air pollution are well known, but the benefits of reducing them are not. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. Our results indicate that the benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are much larger than the costs. This is a call for action.

We also describe a virus-like particle (VLP) vaccine platform that can be used to produce this variant in large quantities. These results provide a promising approach for the development of a vaccine that can be used to address the global COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been responsible for multiple outbreaks throughout the world. The earliest Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period in Eurasia have revealed key evolutionary steps that led to its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor. However, the number of genomes is too small to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period, a trend not observed in other pathogens for which ancient genomes are available. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work provides a unique perspective on the early history of plague and its potential adaptation to its vector. It also highlights the potential for ancient DNA to provide insights into the origins of pathogens and their adaptation to their vectors

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings have implications for understanding the 2016 and 2020 presidential elections and beyond.

The fate of carbon (C) in agricultural soils is a critical component of the global carbon cycle and climate change. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has resulted in the release of massive amounts of C to the atmosphere. This study shows that the management of annual cropping systems on grasslands can be used to sequester C in the soil. This finding has implications for the design of climate-smart agricultural systems and the role of grasslands in the global carbon cycle.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors for spillover and spread of viruses from animals to humans, and a web tool to rank the risk of 887 wildlife viruses. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting risk ranking framework and web tool can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a roadmap for the systematic identification of zoonotic threats and the development of strategies for their prevention and control.

Nectar is a reward that many plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is often used as an indicator of the reward’s quality, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. This work identifies a convergent adaptation in two species of hummingbird-visited plants and provides evidence that the red color of nectar is a highly favored trait. Our findings suggest that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides insight into the evolution of the most important reward in nature. The genetic structure of modern Europeans is strongly correlated with geography, but the processes that shaped it are still poorly understood. We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between 490 and 650 AD. Our results indicate that they had a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we show that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical to the early detection and response to emerging and reemerging infectious diseases. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the causes of undifferentiated febrile illness and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to identify the causes of undifferentiated illness in other resource-scarce settings. This study was conducted in a resource-scarce setting, and the results can be generalized to other resource-scarce settings. DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template and anchors to the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp to form a holoenzyme. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for lagging strand synthesis. This work also provides a unique platform for the development of new tools for studying the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme. The origin of life is one of the most important questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of genetically encoded proteins, the replication of genetic information was accomplished by RNA molecules. In this study, we demonstrate that an RNA polymerase ribozyme can replicate RNA molecules, amplify them, and synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers and ribozymes. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the realization of the RNA world. (Show more)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a key factor in understanding the spatial distribution of economic and social outcomes. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical dynamics of cities.

COVID-19 is a severe infectious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment of COVID-19 is still in the stage of clinical trial. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess can be toxic. The ability of fungi to sequester copper in the form of isocyanide-containing metabolites suggests a role for these compounds in the maintenance of copper homeostasis. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings provide insight into the role of isocyanide-containing natural products in the environment and in the biology of fungi. The identification of copper-binding natural products in fungi may also lead to the development of new antifungal agents. (A)

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature polymorph of silica, on Mars is a significant discovery. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary mudstone at the base of the sedimentary sequence at the base of the Gale crater sequence is consistent with the hypothesis that the sedimentary rocks were deposited in a lacustrine environment. The presence of tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and amorphous silica in the same sample suggests that the sediment source was the crater wall/rim/central peak region. The presence of magnetite and mixed-cation salts and oxides in the same sample suggests that the sediment source was a region of acidic leaching. The presence of tridymite, magnetite, and mixed-cation salts and oxides in the same sample suggests that the sediment source was a region of acidic leaching. Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agricultural crops. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that this change is driven by the increasing frequency of late-spring frosts. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees to frost damage are region-specific, and that these strategies are changing in response to climate change. Our findings have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this subset of cells is unclear. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the transition of a subset of Th17 cells to Th1-like cells and that this process requires the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Th17 cells can also provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Understanding the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to inflammatory bowel disease may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.
