Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by the degeneration of motor neurons, which are the cells responsible for generating muscle movement. The disease is progressive, and death occurs within 3 to 5 years of onset. The cause of the disease is unknown, and there are no effective treatments. We have developed a method to convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into induced astrocytes, which are the cells that surround and protect the motor neurons. We have shown that these astrocytes are toxic to motor neurons, and that this toxicity is caused by the astrocytes themselves. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify treatments for ALS. This work will also help to understand the role of astrocytes in other neurodegenerative diseases. (Read more)

The gut microbiota of ticks is a complex community that influences the transmission of pathogens to vertebrate hosts. Here, we show that the tick antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp) is expressed in the gut and that it alters the composition of the gut microbiota. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This study provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector to enhance transmission. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail and the pygostyle are critical for understanding the origin of flight and the evolution of the modern avian bauplan. However, the currently limited known diversity of early branching pygostylians obscures our understanding of this major transition in avian evolution. Here, we describe a basal pygostylian, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China that adds important information about early members of the short-tailed bird group. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. This study also provides new insights into the evolution of the flight apparatus and the development of the avian tail. (Less)

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This ability is important for animals to adapt to their environment, and it is also important for animals to be camouflaged. In this study, we show that the color of some vertebrates can be changed by the presence of a specific protein. This protein is able to bind biliverdin, a molecule that is responsible for the green color of plants. This discovery is important because it shows that the color of vertebrates can be changed by the presence of a specific protein, and it also shows that the color of vertebrates can be changed by the presence of a specific protein that binds biliverdin.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and metastasis. We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modifications on mRNA. ALKBH5 expression is increased in breast cancer stem cells, and is induced by hypoxia. ALKBH5 expression is required for the maintenance of breast cancer stem cells, and is associated with the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. Thus, ALKBH5 may represent a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. This study provides insight into the role of m6A modification in the regulation of breast cancer stem cells. (Read more)

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. It is also one of the most fragile. The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was easily damaged. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical to understanding the causes and mechanisms of extinction and recovery. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly variable during the extinction, and the recovery was protracted. These results provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The age model will also be critical for evaluating the role of rate-dependent processes in the extinction and recovery. The results will have a major impact on our understanding of the causes of the extinction and its aftermath. (Less)

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the excessive immune response against the intestinal microbiota. The pathogenesis of IBD is complex and involves multiple factors, such as genetic factors, environmental factors, and the immune response. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays a crucial role in the intestinal immune response. We generated intestinal epithelial cell-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. Our study provides a new perspective for the treatment of IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2 at 3.0-Å resolution. The structure of the spike in complex with ACE2 reveals a range of conformational states, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. The structure of the spike in complex with ACE2 may provide a basis for the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that, under mild assumptions, every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an equilibrium, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We also show that the existence of an equilibrium is preserved under small perturbations of the payoff function. This result is a step toward the study of the computational complexity of repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y for the total US population. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are of great importance in chemistry, biology, and materials science. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms can be modified under pressure, and that these properties can be used to predict and explain the behavior of chemical compounds under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can affect the carbon cycle. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are uncertain, and the effects of human ignitions are often ignored. We show that human ignitions can have a large effect on the carbon cycle, and that climate change may amplify this effect. Our results suggest that climate change may reduce warming, but that human ignitions may be needed to achieve this.

The symbiosis between animals and their associated microbes is a major component of the animal kingdom. The mutualism between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is a classic example of this relationship. In this study, we show that the squid provides a single glycan to its symbiont at a specific time of day, which is required for the persistence of the symbiont. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. We propose that this strategy is used by other animal hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This study provides a new perspective on the role of nutrients in the regulation of symbiosis. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data, which we call discourse atom topic modeling (DATM). We use a generative model to identify a set of latent topics that are represented as a sequence of topics. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives, which are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data. It can be applied to many domains and is likely to be useful in many applications. It can also be extended to other types of data. We hope it will be widely used.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the Black Death in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. The disease was introduced into Europe via the ancient Silk Road system, and the climate conditions that preceded the outbreaks were studied in the past. However, the climate conditions in the source regions of the disease are not known. We show that the climate conditions in the Asian harbors of the Silk Road were favorable for the introduction of the disease into Europe, and that the climate conditions in Europe were favorable for the establishment of the disease in Europe. This study provides evidence for the importance of climate conditions in the source regions for the introduction of the disease into Europe. (Show more)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web, but their populations are currently in decline along the Pacific Coast. We show that this decline is associated with a virus that is transmitted by starfish. This is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality in starfish.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study also provides a proof of principle for the use of antibody-based therapies in the treatment of AML. This approach

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the island was settled by multiple waves of migration, with a recent demographic growth. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, and that the settlement was sex biased. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide a better understanding of the history of Madagascar, and they have implications for the study of human evolution and migration.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate gene expression. Some of these RNAs encode a small protein that also functions as a small RNA. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases the activity of glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, a key enzyme in the metabolism of glycerol. The protein also interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress carbon utilization genes. These results suggest that the protein and RNA compete for the same binding sites on the target genes. This is an example of a mechanism that has evolved to fine-tune the activity of small RNAs.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of approved vaccines and antibodies. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. We demonstrate the utility of our approach by optimizing the binding affinity of a human antibody, P36-5D2, to SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. Our optimized antibody is ∼10- to 600-fold more potent than the original antibody against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be used to optimize other protein molecules, such as vaccines and therapeutics, to improve their effectiveness against emerging variants. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work provides a new approach to antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. (Show more)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the US. However, their assessments are qualitative and subjective, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show that the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is based on the assessments of thousands of crop experts, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the CPC survey is a valuable source of information that can be used to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop conditions. This information can be used to improve the accuracy of crop forecasts and to support decision-making in the agricultural sector. Our findings have implications for the development of early warning systems for agricultural production, as well as for the understanding of the dynamics of agricultural production and the role of crop experts in this process.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the nervous system that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the passage of time. We show that this mechanism is suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time within dynamic memory registers. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we present the results of a global synthesis of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and 27 temperature manipulation studies. Our analysis reveals that the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration does not change with warming in most biomes, but does change in deserts and boreal forests. This study provides a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. Our results suggest that soil respiration may be more responsive to warming in colder climates, which may have important implications for the global carbon cycle. However, further research is needed to understand the mechanisms underlying these results. (Show more)

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, as it is marked by a large number of unknown events. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. This model can be used to predict the evolutionary trajectories of other genomes that have undergone similar changes in their functional constraints. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 rainfall deficit in southwestern South Africa was the worst in more than a century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this event by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our results also show that the risk of drought in SSA is not limited to the 2015–2017 event but is likely to increase in the future. This highlights the need for urgent adaptation measures. Our results are based on a high-resolution large ensemble, which is a unique feature of this study. The results are also robust to the choice of emission scenario. This study is a step towards a better understanding of the role of anthropogenic climate change in the occurrence of extreme droughts. However, the results are limited

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has been a major advance in the study of materials. The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the Trinity test, is a unique event in the history of science. The discovery of the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal in the aftermath of the Fukushima nuclear disaster provides a new perspective on the history of the discovery of quasicrystals and the potential for the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems in the future.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the O2-dependent enzyme. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase that has been implicated in neuroinflammation. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a greater proinflammatory role in the later stage of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may also provide insights into the pathophysiology of EAE and other neuroinflammatory diseases. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex disorder with a large number of risk genes. It is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. We used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggests that the forgetting process is a common target for autism-risk genes. This study also provides a new approach to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the effects of real news video content on the physiological responses of participants. Results offer the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but they also serve to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.” (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, but its physiological role has been difficult to determine because of the difficulty in studying its function in vivo. Here, we show that mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 can be gain- or loss-of-function mutations, and that these mutations can be used to study the physiological role of the CRAC channel in vivo. We show that Stormorken syndrome is caused by gain-of-function mutations in STIM1, and that ORAI1 p.P245L can be used to study the physiological role of ORAI1 in vivo. These studies advance our understanding of the physiological role of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. (Stormorken syndrome is also known as congenital miosis and tubular aggregate myopathy.) (Read more)

The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the endocytic machinery and that the release of aggregates requires active transport. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses that cause severe outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of bats. This protein, which we named Myotis pilosus MTX (Mtx), selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. Mtx potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by Mtx but were reversed by interfering with the effects of Mtx on LTA4H or exogenous LTB4 administration. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting Mtx-LTA4H. Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a critical regulator of cell growth. We report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), a key enzyme in one-carbon metabolism. We show that the inhibitor blocks cancer cell growth, and that this effect is rooted in the enzyme’s role in one-carbon metabolism. We also show that cancer cells have unique metabolic vulnerabilities, and that these vulnerabilities can be exploited to develop more effective cancer therapies. This work provides a foundation for the development of more effective cancer therapies. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic causes. These mutations are linked to the formation of intracellular inclusion bodies that contain a variety of proteins that do not share obvious characteristics other than coaggregation. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a consequence of the ALS-linked mutations, or it may be a consequence of the ALS-linked mutations in the context of the cellular environment. Understanding the underlying mechanisms may lead to new therapeutic approaches. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The results are expected to have broad implications for the design of photonic devices for quantum information processing and quantum simulation. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of the plant kingdom. The first flowering plants were aquatic plants that lived below the surface of the water. The study of the earliest flowering plants is difficult because of the lack of fossils. The study of Montsechia, a very early flowering plant, is presented here.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, but the evolution of the human pathogen parvovirus B19 (B19V) has been difficult to study. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya. We also find that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. These results emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. They also provide a unique opportunity to study the evolution of humans and viruses over the last 70,000 years. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This study shows that the acceleration is due to the warming climate, not to changes in the measurement system. The results are consistent with the IPCC 5th Assessment Report (AR5) model projections.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain is increasing with age, but that this increase is not uniform across the population. Pain is also increasing with education, but only for those without a bachelor’s degree. These patterns suggest that the erosion of working-class life is having a negative impact on health.

Here, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography in this area, providing a detailed picture of the fate of the leaving group in a key enzyme reaction. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions, and the potential of this approach to provide a detailed picture of the active site environment and the role of each component in the reaction. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe human coronavirus that emerged in 2012. The continued emergence of MERS cases with a high case fatality rate stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that the broad-spectrum antiviral remdesivir, which is in clinical trials for the treatment of Ebola virus disease, effectively inhibited MERS coronavirus (MERS-CoV) replication in vitro, and showed efficacy against SARS-CoV in a mouse model. Prophylactic and therapeutic remdesivir treatment in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection prevented disease, inhibited virus replication, and reduced the severity of lung lesions. These data support the testing of remdesivir treatment in a clinical trial for MERS-CoV infection. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. The symbiosis between animals and their associated microbes is a major component of the animal kingdom. The mutualism between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is a classic example of this relationship. In this study, we show that the squid provides a single glycan to its symbiont at a specific time of day, which is required for the persistence of the symbiont. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for its own persistence. We propose that this strategy is used by other animal hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This study provides a new perspective on the role of nutrients in the regulation of symbiosis. (Show more)

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the function of DNA. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered MERS viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses trafficked past cell-surface proteases and into endosomes, whereas precleaved viruses used endosomal proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. This approach could be used to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals served in other settings, such as schools and hospitals. Here we use quantitative proteomics to show that the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion by oncogenes, and that this remodeling is harmonized by common biological themes. Vote-by-mail is a popular policy that has been implemented in many countries around the world. In the United States, however, it is not widely used. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. We also find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect the partisan balance of the US Congress. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that is worth considering for the United States.

SARS-CoV-2 is the cause of the COVID-19 pandemic. The role of accessory proteins in the virus’s life cycle is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is unique to SARS-CoV-2 and may be involved in immune suppression and evasion. The structure reveals a dimerization interface that is unique to SARS-CoV-2, as well as a second interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. These interfaces may be involved in immune suppression and evasion. The structure also reveals a unique fold for SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which may be involved in the virus’s ability to form large-scale assemblies. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of the unique properties of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema, which is a life-threatening condition. However, the mechanisms underlying this condition are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats and that this effect is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of hypoxic cerebral edema and suggest that CRFR1 agonists may be useful for the treatment of this condition. The scientific enterprise is in the midst of a revolution. The amount of data being generated is growing exponentially, and the sophistication of the statistical methods being used to analyze these data is increasing rapidly. This paper describes a new challenge that arises in this context. We describe a way of thinking about this challenge and illustrate it with three examples: forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the repair of ischemic tissues. In this study, we demonstrate that the transcription factor Ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the formation of functional vascular ECs (ETVECs) from human adult skin fibroblasts. The ETV2-induced ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in mice. These results indicate that ETV2 provides a promising approach for the generation of ETVECs, which can be used for the repair of ischemic tissues. Furthermore, the ETVECs can be used as a source of endothelial cells for the generation of vascular plexus to regenerate organs, such as the liver. These results provide a new strategy for the treatment of ischemic disorders and the regeneration of organs. (Show more)

The discovery of the ligand(s) for the orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has been a major advance in our understanding of the biology of these receptors. In this study, we show that the zebrafish genome encodes three ligands for Alk and Ltk, and that these ligands are essential for the development of iridophores and pigment cells in the eye and body. These findings establish a physiological link between the ligands and the RTKs and demonstrate that the ligands are essential for the development of these tissues. This study provides a model system for the study of ligand-activated RTKs and their physiological roles. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING deficiency in β-cells and insulin target tissues beneficially alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance. However, STING deficiency in β-cells impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. Moreover, STING deficiency in β-cells decreased nuclear localization of Pax6, a transcription factor that might be associated with defective glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. Influenza A viruses are the main cause of human and animal influenza epidemics and pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. We show that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction decreases the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (truncated)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in blood vessels. The development of these lesions is associated with the activation of a variety of proatherosclerotic factors. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of a new class of antiatherosclerotic drugs. Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results highlight the need for increased management of human-caused wildfires. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a key factor in understanding the spatial distribution of economic and social outcomes. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to synthetic pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the infection of cells in the brain and the production of virus in the blood are thought to be important. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the infection of cells in the brain is rapid, the production of virus in the blood is rapid, and the infection of cells in the brain while producing virus in the blood is long. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. Our results can help to inform the development of antiviral therapies. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a widespread phenomenon that is considered a key indicator of the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying causes of the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic interactions between coral and symbiont are a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress increases the energy demand of the coral host, which is compensated by the degradation of amino acids. The resulting shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont subsequently promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the host from the environment. In the absence of tumor growth, the epithelium is able to maintain its barrier function. However, in the presence of tumors, the epithelium becomes dysfunctional, leading to a dysbiotic microbiome and a regenerative response. This feedback loop is critical for tumor growth and organismal lifespan. Our work identifies a mechanism that controls the activity of the JNK pathway, which is critical for the maintenance of the intestinal barrier and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for the development of therapies that target the microbiome and the JNK pathway to treat cancer and improve host–microbe interactions. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Although the majority of breast cancers are estrogen receptor–positive, a small percentage of tumors are resistant to endocrine therapy. In this study, we show that the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is expressed in a small percentage of breast cancers and is up-regulated following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression is associated with the development of breast cancer stemness and metastasis. Finally, we demonstrate that targeting ROR1 with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab enhances the response to chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Read more)

The timing of the onset of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is one of the most important climate events of the last 20,000 y. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions, exactly at the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a climate response that plausibly contributed to the acceleration of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also reveals that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the poor and undernourished. However, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to protect biodiversity. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management efforts to protect both food security and species diversity. This is particularly important in regions where rivers are under threat from climate change, land use change, and other stressors. Our results highlight the need for a more holistic approach to managing freshwater ecosystems. (Less)

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the ability to regenerate is lost after early development. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery has important implications for our understanding of the molecular control of regeneration in the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the mammalian CNS may be more plastic than previously thought, and that the adult nervous system may be more capable of regeneration than previously appreciated.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences, and it is essential for the proper development of all organisms. In eukaryotes, the process is initiated by the binding of proteins to specific sequences in the DNA, and the resulting binding sites are often referred to as recombination hotspots. In this study, we describe the distribution of hotspots in the genome of a flowering plant, and we find that hotspots are distributed throughout the genome, with some regions having more hotspots than others. This study provides a detailed view of the distribution of hotspots in a eukaryotic genome.

The brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to reflect the underlying anatomy and physiology. However, the anatomical basis of these networks is still poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic organization of the brain is highly reproducible and can be used to identify and validate functional networks. We also show that the metabolic organization of the brain is altered in Parkinson’s disease, and that this abnormality can be corrected by dopaminergic therapy. These results provide a new perspective on the organization of the brain and its potential use as a biomarker for disease.

The 5′ cap structure of messenger RNA (mRNA) is known to regulate translation. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ cap structure in eukaryotes, which we call the 5′ NAD+ cap. We show that this cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We also show that the 5′ NAD+ cap is produced cotranscriptionally, suggesting that it may regulate mRNA stability and translation. Our results provide a new mechanism for controlling gene expression in eukaryotes.

The role of a protein in cancer is often determined by its expression level. However, this approach may miss the potential functions of the protein. Here, we show that the expression level of a protein does not always correlate with its function. We identified a protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), that is highly expressed in breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency in TNBC cells results in autophagy, AMPK activation, and decreased mTOR and Wnt/β-catenin activity. These findings suggest that FSIP1 may be a promising target for TNBC therapy. Alcohol dependence is a complex disease with a high mortality rate. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which may be related to the development of psychological symptoms. The gut microbiota is also altered in these subjects, and the composition and activity of the microbiota are associated with the gut barrier. These results suggest that the gut microbiota may be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The production of volatile compounds is a major contributor to the flavor of many fruits and vegetables. In this study, we identify a gene essential for the production of a wide range of nitrogenous volatile compounds in tomato fruit. The underlying gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of volatile compounds in tomato fruit and will be of interest to researchers studying the flavor of other fruits and vegetables. The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is frequently investigated separately from other factors that may influence ecosystem processes. Here we show that changes in temperature can alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, and that this relationship is more complex than previously thought. Our results highlight the importance of considering the effects of climate change on the thermal tolerance of species, and the role that biodiversity loss may play in exacerbating the impacts of environmental warming. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning and the services they provide to society. (Show more)

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub of the hippocampal circuit, and its neurons are thought to encode the spatial layout of the environment. However, the organization of the MEC is still poorly understood, in part because of the difficulty of studying the complex structure of this region in vivo. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to study the organization of neurons in the superficial layers of MEC and adjacent parasubiculum in freely behaving mice. Our data suggest that the organization of the MEC is more complex than previously thought. In particular, the neurons that encode the spatial layout of the environment are strongly coupled among themselves, but weakly coupled to other cell types. These findings have implications for our understanding of the function of the MEC. (Show more)

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The underlying cause of the disease is unknown, but it is thought to involve a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system of specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. These units, termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are formed by tightly intertwined striosomes and dopamine-containing dendrites. We suggest that the bouquets are critical to the function of the nigral system and that disruption of the bouquets may contribute to the development of Parkinson’s disease. The findings have implications for our understanding of the function of the nigral system and the development of neurodegenerative disorders. They also suggest that the bouquet system may be a target for the development of new treatments for Parkinson’s disease and other disorders of the dopamine system.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We have long sought to understand how we know when two people are connecting with each other. We show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of language, the development of social networks, and the design of social technologies.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN cells (SANCs) are able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand by integrating the membrane and store clocks. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the membrane clock in SANCs. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SANCs and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. Moreover, STIM1 influenced SAN function by regulating ionic fluxes in SANCs, including activation of a store-operated Ca2+ current, a reduction in L-type Ca2+ current, and enhancing the activities of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the function of Si in plant defense against insect herbivory has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivory. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and for the function of macrophages. They also suggest that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase may be a target for the treatment of inflammatory diseases. This study also provides a new tool for the study of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be based on the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rates of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the passage of time. We show that this mechanism can support the binding of linguistic features over time, and it can support the integration of information over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in the field of plant biology. This is due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are the key design parameters for the internalization and gene silencing efficiencies. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step forward in the field of plant biology and opens up new avenues for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. (Show more)

Nutrient inputs to lakes and reservoirs are often dominated by small tributaries, but this is rarely considered in nutrient management efforts. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to large water bodies, especially in the form of dissolved inorganic nutrients. This can lead to a greater potential for algal blooms in coastal areas, especially given the likelihood that their plumes become trapped and then overlap in the nearshore zone. Our findings reveal an underappreciated role that small streams may play in driving coastal eutrophication in large water bodies. Expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This work highlights the need to consider the full range of watershed sizes when managing nutrient inputs to lakes and reservoirs. Our findings have implications for the management of nutrient inputs to lakes and reservoirs worldwide.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is highly selective with respect to the chemical concentrations it can access. We find that the system is biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the system is biased toward states that extremize the cosmological constant.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that the effects of the antibodies on the cortical microcircuit can lead to changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We validate a dynamic model of the cortical microcircuitry and show that it can explain the effects of the antibodies on the cortical microcircuit. Finally, we show that the same changes in the cortical microcircuit can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in the mouse model of the disease. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by the antibodies. This work may help in the development of new therapeutic strategies for this disease. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2,000 years. The cause of this warming is still under debate. Here, we present evidence for a rapid warming event that occurred ∼304 Ma, which was superimposed on a glacial state. We show that the warming event was linked to a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the warming event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean, which likely enhanced the thermocline and increased nutrient fluxes. Our findings provide insights into the mechanisms of rapid warming events and may help to understand the current rapid warming. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is a promising tool for reducing deforestation, but it is not a silver bullet. Rather, certification must be part of a broader strategy to reduce deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit complex that is essential for the last steps of exocytosis. It is conserved across kingdoms, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases. The exocyst complex is difficult to study in humans because of its complexity and the severity of the disease. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an individual is often a defining characteristic of its phenotype. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes, or by multiple interacting loci, resulting in more than two sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination loci in a species with four possible sex classes. We find that multiple loci can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics can be increased by the acquisition of a new sex determination locus. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. (Show more)

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of lipofuscin, a yellow pigment that is a mixture of oxidized and degraded retinal compounds. We show that the accumulation of the oxidized retinal compound A2E in the retina is reduced in mice treated with a Fe chelator. This reduction is due to a reduction in the oxidation of A2E by reactive oxygen species and Fenton chemistry products. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystem functioning, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in shaping the structure of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, is associated with the evolution of modularity in their feeding apparatus. Our findings contribute to a broader perspective on the evolution of predatory specialization, and help understand how morphological innovations have shaped present-day food webs. This work contributes to the development of a more complete understanding of the evolution of predators and their role in ecosystems.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. The discovery of a hominin hand from 1.42 My ago provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This discovery also highlights the importance of the Turkana Basin in the study of human evolution. The basin has produced a large number of hominin fossils, including the earliest known evidence for modern human behavior. The basin is also the site of the most recent discovery of a Neandertal fossil. The basin is thus a unique place to study the evolution of the human hand. (Less)

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a critical pathway for cell growth. We have identified a small-molecule inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), a key enzyme in one-carbon metabolism. We show that this inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and that it is particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, we have identified a metabolic pathway that can be targeted to kill cancer cells, and a metabolic deficiency that can be targeted to kill lymphoma cells. These findings have implications for the development of new cancer therapies. (truncated)

The importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which are important sources of vitamins, particularly vitamin A. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase consumption of fruits and vegetables, which is important for meeting dietary vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries.

Modern agriculture is a highly mechanised system, with the use of farm machinery increasing food production by a factor of 10 in the last century. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that this trend is a consequence of the increasing size of modern farm vehicles, which are now approaching the weight of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods.
